Comment: Carbon capture storage cost $1.5 billion for about a 3% reduction in saskatchewan's pollution from coal plants. That is well over $1000 for each person in the province and that will need to be increased by several hundred percent to get the province where it needs to go on carbon reduction.

Even a modest increase in the consumption of coal will vastly increase pollution and leave the tiny amount of carbon capture far behind.

CCS is WAY more costly than carbon pricing. For a conservative like Wall to be for CCS and against carbon pricing is just plain stupid. Nobody in their right mind will purchase it except for specific industrial applications, i.e., not as part of a global carbon reduction strategy.

On top of that, it is still experimental. Saskatchewan has been flogging CCS for about 10 years and has only got about one year of steady operation out of it. Real great redrider.

and SK doesn't even own it. So the province won't get a nickel back on its investment by licensing etc.

Every time someone says 'That's just the way it is' about poor animal care in animal control centers, I can confidently cite them as proof it can be done better, because it IS being done better. Comment: I can honestly say that I don't understand addiction.  When I went to the pain center for fibromyalgia the doctor put me on roxicodone and morphine daily.  I felt like a zombie for about a month.  After that I chose to stay in pain rather than miss out on life.  I quit the pain clinic and asked my doctor for something just to take the edge off.  He prescribed tramadol which wasn't considered a narcotic over 10yrs ago. 

To this day I still take tramadol.  But also lyrica. I have more pain free days.  However I don't feel addicted in anyway to the medication prescribed to me.  Perhaps some people are just more susceptible to addiction than others?  Honestly If taken as prescribed you don't overdose.  Maybe culling is a natural reaction to over population?

Comment: I'm not at all convinced by the authors' arguments. First and foremost, Donald Trump's electoral mandate was to "drain the swamp." He has the democratic authority, given by the people, to bypass the usual bureaucratic jungle and get things done.

Second,  it's yet to be determined if all his executive orders are within the president's constitutional power. Some are likely to be non-contentious. But even those that are will have to be tested in court. Best we wait and see the result before declaring saying the president is acting illegally.

Finally, which of Trump's orders has drawn the most ire from some quarters? His 90-day suspension of immigration from seven countries. Given the authority assumed by previous presidents for guarding the security of the USA- without any push-back from the public- Trump's order is exceedingly moderate. Currently 55% of Americans' agree with it.

Comment: RRSPs work fine for deferring tax to a certain level of income and a certain level of savings.  And you do get to a point where you risk paying more tax on the proceeds than what you saved.  If you're in that position, you're probably doing well.
As an aside, you have to be careful paying yourself in dividends because it can hurt your CPP proceeds. Many people don't know about 'knock out' years, of which you're only allowed 7 or 8.  If you've been paying yourself dividends instead of salary for a while, then you may need to take your CPP at 60, to maximize your pay out.  All a bit beside the point.
The fact is that the government will only let us defer just so much tax, and then we have to pay the piper.  I'm personally okay with the rules, but I feel it should be different for doctors and other professionals in some way.  But not through income sprinkling.  There are quite a few valid points here about the inflexibility of RRSPs for entrepreneurs and professionals.

Comment: I'd imagine that climate change is one big reason fires have become more frequent since 1987. Fire season is some 70 days longer now than it was in 1970. Winter starts later, ends earlier and doesn't get as cold as it  did before. And this has led to an explosion in bark beetle infestations, which, in some places, have killed literally millions of trees. 

Funny how Dr. Zybach doesn't mention any of this stuff.

Nor does he say anything about the steady diminution of old growth through intensive logging, the steady expansion of logging road networks into isolated areas--which fragments wildlife habitat and mature forests and exposes more land to man-made fire sources --or the continual cutting and replanting of private land, which destroys biodiversity, creates openings for flammable brush, and dries out the forest floor, creating more fuel.

Why would an expert on wildfires not mention any of this? Could this be thinly disguised pro-logging propaganda? Perish the thought . . .

Comment: The most significant impact of Columbus and other Europeans' arrival in the Americas is the exchange of plants, animals and infectious diseases between the two continents.  With the so called Columbian Exchange some very important domestic animals, such as cattle, chicken, goat, horse, pig and sheep were brought to the Americas.  Important food sources such as wheat, barley, rice, rye, sugar, carrots, apples, peach and pears were introduced in America.  While Europeans killed many American natives, the vast numbers, up to 70% – 80%, were killed by Euro-Asian diseases such as smallpox, influenza, typhoid and cholera.  The Americas did not have a domesticated beast of burden the closest animal was the alpaca.  The most important plants and animals from the Americas were corn, potato, peanut, tomato and tobacco.  It is believed syphilis originated in the Americas.

Comment: I grew up trapping. Trapping _is_ horrific. We lived a semi-subsistence lifestyle in hard country. Every one of my 10 siblings, as well as my father trapped. None of us continued to trap into adulthood. My father, who was probably the best aerial hunter I ever have known, became an environmentalist as well as an advocate for animals in his later life. (He was the best armed environmentalist that I know of :)) I am a great admirer of Temple Grandin and the work that she has done to make slaughtering more humane. (No animal that my father raised was ever sold for slaughter - when a cow stopped producing it was put down on the farm where it had lived its entire live, in the most humane way possible). I don't eat much meat any more.

Alaska public finance rests on a three-legged stool - The PFD program (our incomplete and fragile version of a "sovereign wealth fund" ; a budget that meets our immediate and long-term Statewide investment and containment needs and responsibilities; and new revenues to sustain the first two. 
The recent Goldsmith-Havelock commentary addresses the PFD leg quite well & sensibly - and that is what it is intended to do. As noted by others, to get the PFD growth in the future, and legislate its uses to fit Alaska needs, is a 2-3 year dialogue, analysis and decision process. Hopefully it will end up doing as much benefit for Alaska residents as Norway and Saudi wealth funds are moving toward. This is just one leg of 3 & a good start!

Comment: But its not really a new model.  It borrows heavily from the Model S.  As Teslas are 'ground-up' designed electric vehicles they are mechanically very simple.  The battery system, motor, drive-train, steering, and suspension are all very similar for Model S, Model X and Model 3.  

I have had a Model S since early 2013.  It was one of the first 6000 vehicles of that model.  I had one issue with a rear passenger window that Tesla fixed within a day at no cost to me.  They even came to my work to pick up the car and give me a high end Model S as a loaner.

The sum total of maintenance that I've done in 4 years is to replace windshield wipers, fill the windshield wiper fluid, put on snow tires, and wash the car.  After 4 years of daily driving, I still think it is the best car I've ever driven.

Comment: Yes, I spent a year talking to Vietnamese from both the North and the South.  I read the personal letters and diaries of NVA Soldiers.  Never once did I hear or read any of them show any affection for Communism.  Both sides wanted a free and independent country, but when Ho Chi Minh couldn't get aid from Eisenhower to fight the French (his first choice), he turned to the Soviets who gave him the arms and money he needed and professed his allegiance to Communism.  Had we not been allies with the French and been in a position to help the Vietminh, Vietnam would be a free and independent Capitalist country today.

The South Vietnamese weren't fond of their dictators, but the war happened because they hated the Communists even more.  The North Vietnamese made a huge miscalculation with the Tet Offensive, believing that when they took the fight to the cities, the people would rise up to support the Communists, and the military would change sides.  The opposite happenened.

Comment: Burning coal is basically burning the earth. Mercury is released into the atmosphere in the process, polluting the air breathed by adults and children living downwind. 
While many people are still convinced the mercury in compact fluorescent light bulbs is a serious hazard t health, it's captured in the bulb and easily recycled through local hardware stores. There is more of a danger from mercury in tuna than that posed by the release from a broken and carefully disposed bulb.
In fact, the amount of mercury produced by burning more coal to power inefficient incandescent bulbs far outweighs any environmental impact from CFLs. Low wattage bulbs, including LEDs, reduce pollution from burning coal.
Now a memory, this benefit came about after industry funded Republicans blocked legislation forcing the elimination of old technology filament bulbs, which are really just small heaters designed to also produce light. 
Removing coal from the grid is an even better step forward.

Comment: Severance pay is technically "pay in lieu of notice".  If the company provides enough notice, they don't need to provide pay in lieu of notice.  

Requiring employees to work through the notice period can be risky business, but it is a legally legitimate option.  Most employers would rather avoid the risks of bitter employees on site and possible sabotage, so they provide pay in lieu of notice.   But the employer plans to continue operations during the notice period until they turn off the lights, then asking employees to work during the notice period is an option.  There is no entitlement to a guaranteed payout, contrary to popular belief.

Comment: The Pope is gonna be critiqued by many for not going far enough in his actions and I can see where people making these criticisms are coming from. The fact that he wrote a preface to a book written by a sex abuse victim on this topic is pretty amazing. So even though people may not like the pace of how this are going, the Pope in his own way is making changes slowly and incrementally that in the long run in the future, will seem substantial.

Comment: Primary care is in dire need of reorganization. My wife just had surgery, and after a few days she was in serious pain and quite worried. Trouble was, it was now Friday afternoon. Her GP office always closes at noon. The specialist surgeon could not be found and his staff showed zero care or concern. The walk-in clinic is full by 10 a.m. and closes at 1:00. So in an Ontario city with over 100,000 people, we're left with...surprise...the hospital emerg department. Crowded, full of infectious disease, s-l-o-w, and uncomfortable. Especially tough when she couldn't sit at all. This is what's available because primary care is still broken after billions in new spending and no improvement in performance or quality.

Instead of using patients as pawns, it would be nice if physicians and our governments could walk the talk on patient- (not provider-) centred care. We've seeded the system with enough money; it's time it earned our support.

Comment: It's amazing how you wrote an article on UBI and didn't look at a single long-term study off it - despite there being hundreds, from all over the world. Comment: When I went to the site listed it showed an average electricity price for the US for 2016 of 13.5 cents/kWh.  The data is from the US Department of Labor. Ontario Hydro shows a blended average for Ontario of 11 cents/kWh reflecting time of use usage. If you do not have a Smart Meter the average price is 10.3 cents/kWh for the first 1000 kWh. If you do have a Smart meter the cost varies from 8.7 to 18 cents/kWh. According to the Ontario Energy Board the average household uses 2/3 of their electricity during off-peak hours.  For San Francisco the 2016 average cost is 19.5 cents/kWh. What is not shown in either case are distribution costs and other administrative costs.

So electricity prices are not so low in the US they are higher than in Ontario.

Gasoline is another story. In Toronto we currently pay  about $1.09/L which is $4.12/gallon.  The US average for 2016 is $2.20/gallon. This is from the same data source. So gasoline prices are much lower in the US than in Canada.

Comment: Here here Wolf Eagle!  For all my life I have been mystified, and more than a little disgusted, that the national anthem is played at the start of (almost all) sporting events. I have always felt that playing the national anthem at sporting events only cheapens and demeans it, in the same way that incorporating the US flag into clothing, especially such items as bathing suits and even underwear, only cheapens and degrades the flag.  Both show a profound disrespect for symbols of national unity, and only help to breed indifference to them.

Comment: For me, the short time that I lived in a high rise apartment tower in Calgary was just about the most miserable time of my life, saving only the year that I spent in the desert of Saudi Arabia.

I was born and raised on a farm. Most of my work life was spent in man camps and small town hotels/motels. 20 years ago I bought a small farm with a grand pre-WW I house. It has been pure bliss restoring the old house and creating my beautiful orchards, gardens, flower beds, and yard.  My retirement is serene and solitary but full of pleasure.

My visitors seem to experience that same serenity. Without fail every visitor to my place is envious of me and expresses a wish to have a life like mine.

Sadly, Canada is now an intensely urban country. My lifestyle is hard work unsuited to most Canadians but it is......oh! so rewarding. Anything that can bring even a small part of my lifestyle to the city is to be encouraged; whether it be greenery, community gardens, open spaces, farmers' markets.

Comment: Stormtrooper,
I'd like to take a shot at your question.  

To begin, whatever else the church may be, it is clearly embedded in human form.  Without that concept, the rest means nothing.

I believe very strongly that to the degree that there is divine influence on the church, that influence comes from our combined wisdom and experience.  There's a reason, for example, the story of Lot remains in the bible, and resonates even today.  Human suffering is very difficult to explain.  Yet, beauty and wisdom can emerge from that, as it can from so many other areas of human experience.  THAT gift is where the divine resides.  When we interact with each other, we're sharing that wisdom, that pain, that joy, that love (etc.)  THAT'S what we have to work with today.  The church's leadership plays this game of saying "no new revelation," while pretty much also stating "... and we hold it all, so you have to obey."  rubbish.  The "divine" within the church cannot be "controlled' by the institution.

Comment: The article should have made a clear distinction that this was either a motor scooter, or an electric mobility scooter used by the disabled.
 
A motor scooter cannot ride on the sidewalk, period. However, an electric mobility scooter (whose top speed cannot exceed 4 mph) ridden by someone who is legally disabled, can ride anywhere people can walk, including sidewalks, and they have a legal right to do so, per the ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act). I'm not saying that gives anyone the right to brandish a weapon in any situation other than self-defense, but you can't impede disabled people on mobility scooters either. Fortunately, most people know and respect that.

Comment: Part 3:
During the 14-month debate over the Affordable Care Act, Republicans pitched expanded pools as an alternative. Democrats incorporated the idea in their legislation, setting up a $5 billion high-risk pool that opened almost immediately after the bill became law. They billed the provision as a stopgap for people with pre-existing conditions who couldn’t get health insurance until Obamacare’s ban on discrimination against the sick took effect in 2014.

Administration officials expected the Obamacare pool, known as the Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan, to cover up to 375,000 people out of as many as 25 million Americans who were uninsured due to pre-existing conditions. It only reached 100,000 enrollees, and their medical claims were so extensive that the Obama administration closed enrollment early in 2013. The program’s medical losses totaled $2 billion in its final year. "

Comment: Perhaps examining Zinke's take on coal taxation might be revealing of his mind set.

What coal producers do is mine the coal and then sell it to a subsidiary company. They pay taxes based on that. The subsidiary company then sells the coal for export at a much higher price but the company does not have to pay any taxes on this now much more valuable coal. Obama had sought to stop this and tax the coal at a more equitable rate. Zinke reversed that.

Why does this matter to us? The taxes from resource extraction are shared among a half dozen states in the west, including Colorado. It seems pretty clear that he is going to support the bottom line far more actively than the interests of the states and the people therein. I don't think this bodes well for public lands.

By all of the cuts, he will make it nearly impossible for any regulation of to occur. Be it national monuments or environment or game and fish or... it's not going to turn out well.

Comment: First of all, for the "anti's" there is no solution that will be acceptable in any way shape or form. 

The big ski jump today is technically obsolete. The COP hill is less than ideal and a 2026 facility can be added to the Nakiska site. Fortunately, ski jumps are a relatively low capital requirement.

Bobsled/skeleton/luge ... As I understand it, the biggest problem with the track is the ammonia refrigeration plant which was fine when COP was outside the city. Comment: I took a year of Latin in high school followed by 3 semesters of Latin at The University of Texas at Austin. My last 2 courses were Virgil's Aeneid and Ovid's Metamorphoses. Had I turned in an English translation on a test anywhere near what JP2 did to our English Mass with it's run on sentences and Latin words such as "consubstantial" and "incarnate", just to name 2 of scores of other words not common to the English language, I would have been lucky to get off with a C- on that exam.

The Collects are the worst. Most of us, and I include myself, can barely keep up with the run on sentences and just give up and tune out the monstrosity of JP2's Missal. Ever tried to follow a Collect spoken by a priest from Africa, Asia, or South America with an unfamiliar dialect? It gets to the point where one is trying to decipher another language! As I recall, JP2's select committee had about 1/3rd or more linguists who did not speak English as their primary language!

Comment: Thanks for your response GL, but I have to take issue with it.

There's solid evidence that there were more extreme storms occurring not only before the industrial revolution and the widespread usage of fossil fuels, but even before man walked the planet-
http://events.nytimes.com/2002/10/25/science/25FLOO.html?mcubz=0
https://www.uvm.edu/cosmolab/people/noren/noren_ms_thesis.pdf

And more recent records of tropical storms and hurricanes >100 yrs show their levels fluctuating similarly before and after the industrial revolution-
https://www.gfdl.noaa.gov/historical-atlantic-hurricane-and-tropical-storm-records/

Finally, data shows that Hurricane Harvey developed in an environment in which atmospheric and ocean temperatures were near normal, and slightly above normal in the Gulf, and any climate change effect would have resulted in only an extra inch of rain-
http://cliffmass.blogspot.com/2017/08/global-warming-and-hurricane-harvey.html?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter

Comment: The viewers and public policy are left with nothing from the Global News coverage.   Yes, rates are going up but Global gave no context or any way to move forward.

The world is moving into an era of decreased energy availability and higher costs due to lower EROI fossil fuels and the transition to renewables.  People are going to be hurt by this and the emphasis has to be on how to minimize the impacts.

We'd do this with programs to conserve and reduce consumption.  Clearly, there needs to be a better job done here and that is what the reporting should focus on.  Global's report flashed an invoice for a family residence in which consumption averaged 5kW per hour, every hour for the month.  That is a huge amount of energy.  

They tried to pin the majority of the blame on solar and wind where most of the increased costs have come from infrastructure upgrades and nuclear refurbishing.

To what end?  Do they want us to go back to coal?  We need constructive not destructive reporting.

Comment: Canada Goose is trying to “bully” Sears Canada Inc. and other retailers through litigation, Sears is alleging in court documents as it hits back at a trademark infringement lawsuit.

The parka maker’s real motive is to curtail the sales of lower-priced winter jackets so Canada Goose can keep selling its products “at a huge mark up,” Sears alleges.

Canada Goose alleges in a lawsuit filed late last year that Sears is selling knock-offs of its highly distinctive coats.

The department store has now filed its statement of defence in Federal Court and is taking direct aim not just at this particular lawsuit, but what the retailer calls Canada Goose’s “campaign of intimidation.”

Canada Goose is trying to claim the exclusive right to sell any winter coat with a fur collar “of any sort” or with a circular logo on its sleeve, Sears alleges in its statement of defence.

Comment: There is a flaw in using odometer readings for the basis of charging Washington State taxpayers under this proposal. If I take my vehicle out of State for a long well earn vacation across the span of these United States; will I be billed for these miles driven on other US State roads? While on this well earned trip, I am paying gas tax as I fill up in the various States that I visit. How will the State account for these non-Washington miles? Will they use self-reporting? Will vehicle owners have to install mileage devices in their vehicles and who will pay for their installation and maintenance?  Reliance on property taxes, sales tax, vehicle licensing fees will never cover the total costs of road maintenance in this State.  Are we going to begin issuing vehicle mileage on the basis of rationing? And, how would we manage such a system without incurring more costs for the administration of such a system.  Businesses will just pass their costs onto the consumers (i.e., taxpayers).

Comment: Karen Avila-Lederhos - I really like the idea of returning to solar time, but ... I have a job that requires daily interaction with people all over the state, which becomes more difficult if Juneau is not on the same timezone as Fairbanks and Fairbanks is not on the same timezone as Nome. And, even if we were, New England is considering a similar move which would put them one hour ahead of New York, meaning Alaska would be six hours behind Boston. As I was on the phone to a supplier this morning who is headquartered in Boston, I thought ... wow, I'd either need to come in at 4 in the morning to make phone calls like this or everybody in Alaska would all be trying for the same two hour window to make these phone calls before Bostonians go home for the day. There's some work you just can't do by email.

So, while it sounds like a great commonsense idea, there's a lot to work out. I am old enough to remember when we were five hours off the East Coast and it wasn't very workable.

Comment: Well Ivo, I have crossed swords with you on climate change before. The so-called hiatus is not real, or if there was one, it has long since been swept away by higher temperatures. 2014, 2015 and 2016 were successively all the hottest years on record. And anyway picking a single year from a trend is statistical nonsense. While I am the first to agree that no single weather event can be blamed on climate change, it is certainly true is that some elements of our climate are certainly changing. And they are changing beyond normal cyclical trends and the changes are increasingly rapid. I probably suggested years ago that you study a short course on climate change. There are lots of courses available and one is available here: https://www.edx.org/course/climate-change-science-ubcx-climate1x-3. I would have much more suspect for what you write if I didn't come across glaring errors such as the "hiatus". You would also understand the vast body of knowledge that  underpins the science.

Working there I became fiends with a guy who's father owned a chain of drugstores and a surgical supply company. He got me a job the next summer driving a truck delivering surgical supplies. The next summer I worked in one of the drugstores. My last summer I inherited a little money so I didn't work. I took one summer class in the morning and then went to the beach in the afternoon. At night we'd go out drinking and dancing. It was the summer of '74, one of the best years of my life.

Comment: Rich, on the surface, I probably have it all.  White, male, educated.  But I still had to work pretty hard to achieve a safe and comfortably lifestyle for me and my family.  I was a fairly hotheaded and anti-establishment youngster, wrote my share of indignant letters to MPs, wore the Impeach Reagan t-shirt, had long hair, and attended a few protests, too.  But as I got older, it became apparent that the best way to effect change in the system was to work diplomatically within it.

I don't see that this approach should be different for Indigenous peoples or anyone else.  Show 'em you have talents and fresh ideas.  Change comes slowly, but it does come.  Righteous indignation and symbolic gestures are far less effective than hard work and well reasoned arguments.

Comment: MSW, you made one historical mistake, claiming that the US labor movement was never tainted by communism.  In fact, communists did play a big role in the labor movement through the 1930s and individuals who had been communists continued to play a role thereafter, despite the red scare of the 1950s. Comment: The only part of benefit to the economy for Site C s the construction phase.  Our grandchildren's grandchildren will be paying off the white elephant.  BC does not need the power and Alberta so far hasn't expressed much interest in buying it.  Power sales to the US have dropped off significantly in the last few years and will continue to do so.  (Vegas now runs on solar and alternatives to the electricity grid are getting more and more viable all the time.)  Ontario now pays US utilities to take power while they gouge their own residents, and the same thing will happen here.  Pulp and paper is one of the main users of industrial power in BC and they are getting to the tipping point where it will be cheaper for them to develop in-house co-generation from their waste than to continue to pay BC Hydro rates.  There is a bigger economic case against Site C than there is for it.

Comment: DieterHH,

You are mistaken. Large utilities in almost every country recognize that solar is the future of electrical generation. Solar is also, by far, the most abundant source of energy available to us. Solar did not make economic sense two years ago but now it does. A very interesting series of reports on the levelized costs of producing electricity from coal, natural gas, nuclear, wind and so on has been produced by the famous investment bank Lazard for years. Have a read through the 10th annual report released in December.

https://www.lazard.com/perspective/levelized-cost-of-energy-analysis-100/

You can then look at the 9th, 8th, 7th ...and earlier reports to get an indication of how rapidly the generation of electricity is changing. The 10th report is already out of date as it does not encompass the rapid drop in solar costs seen in 2017. Solar is not as advantageous in Canada as in other countries but it can still make a contribution.

Comment: The problem, a political one, will have to be solved. Our current method of drawing electoral districts significantly advantages rural areas–at the same time that those areas are rapidly losing population to urban America. 
Municipal areas are the drivers of state economies, but in many Republican-controlled states, the urban economy is subjected to decisions made by a predominantly rural legislature. Not surprisingly, tax policies and distribution formulas favor rural areas with diminishing populations over growing urban and suburban communities.
Unfortunately, guestsquared, you live in a modern nation where wealth generation capacity is greater in urban than in rural areas. 
The needs of people in rural areas must be factored into any equation but greater political clout naturally belongs to the wealth-generating population centers.
Modern societies cannot afford to allow less dynamic economic actors to hold sway over the more dynamic.

Comment: twy4Dolphin: Over the last 15 or 20 years, the City of Eugene has considered something like 20 different local funding sources to pay for different parts of the transportation system. Lots of other ways have been considered, and determined to be worse than the GO Bonds on the ballot now.

I agree that a property tax to pay for streets isn’t perfect. But the reality is that far too little federal and state funding to fix streets is forthcoming. We own our own city streets, and it is going to be our responsibility to pay for doing so, one way or another, and if not now then paying much more later to reconstruct failing streets.

There is no free lunch, and having homeowners pay a modest amount to maintain streets that all of us use, whether driving, riding a bus, bicycling or walking, is reasonable and generally fair.

Comment: Whether you want to reevaluate everything in the US constitution is your business but it is strictly a non sequitur  in a discussion on the  relevance of Second Amendment in 21st century. Second Amendment says :
" A well regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms, shall not be infringed."
One can argue that "millitias" are no longer needed for "the security of a free state", given that the US possesses the biggest army.  Also even if you argue about "the right of the people to keep and bear arms", does it mean all arms? Can I own a tank? How about Napalm? Clearly there can and should be reasonable restrictions on what kind of arms can one bear. Comment: If the standard deduction doubles, most people would save in taxes even if the mortgage interest and state/local taxes deductions completely disappeared. The simplest reason for this is that only about 30% of individual tax returns actually itemize - the rest take the standard deduction.

Even middle-class people who currently itemize would likely save. For example, a married Colorado couple (no kids) who buys a median-priced home ($440k in Denver in April 2017, 20% down, 30 years at 3.75%) and has the median household income ($71k in Denver Metro in 2015) would save about $1100 in federal income tax by taking the doubled standard deduction. That's presuming they have no itemized deductions other than mortgage interest, state income tax, and property tax.

Comment: The Elliott has always been undervalued, even just considering the dollar amount they sold their timber for. Their standing timber sales averaged only around $240 per thousand board feet. The Elliott's mission was unique among the state forests... to maximize the return to K12 schools, NOT to supply a few big domestic mills (especially Roseburg Forest Products and Seneca) with premium grade 120 year old logs sold for less than scabby second growth.

To make it even less profitable, state Foresters ran up ridiculous sale preparation costs just to clear cut, burn, spray, and replant.

Then, of course, the enviro attorneys sucked out what little juice was left in the Elliott's timber sale program with expensive litigation and huge settlement fees.

There are better ways to profitably and sustainably log a forest!

Comment: Like it or not, some people have deeply felt religious concerns about homosexuality. Those concerns are supported, and even codified, by some established religious traditions. That’s a reality that can’t just be ignored, however repugnant we find it.

Religious freedom isn’t just for those we agree with. I find the idea of refusing service to somebody based on personal religious beliefs highly problematic, but that doesn’t mean I dismiss out of hand a person’s right to do so.

Comment: Hey, there, Joe.  Interested in your "huge flood of illegal immigration."  

Illegal it is, a "huge flood" it is not.  

Canada's last huge flood of immigrants occurred way back in 1913, the year Canada accepted--and I mean accepted; as in "Approved"--400,000 immigrants.  That's about 100,000 more than ALL the classes of immigrants accepted in Canada last year.  Back then, the Canadian population was about 7 million.  So, if the proportion was the same as our 2016 population, it would mean 1.5 million newcomers in one year.  Wow.  THAT, my friend, is a "huge flood", not this teeny, tiny trickle of border jumper, a mere fraction of the refugees planned for this year (14%, or about 44,000.)

Got more good news to make your day! Haitians have routinely suffered a HUGE rate of refusal.  Most of them--even before they started border-jumping--were denied.  In the first 6 months of 2015, Canada accepted just 38% of those who wanted in. 

Doesn't this just make your day?

Comment: The biggest problem is that the electrical grid will not handle  a major shift to EV. The grid can handle the current small percentage. It will be a much different story with 90+ % of the vehicles being EV.  First the energy from 100+ million tonnes of oil must now from electrical production. Currently over 30% of our energy consumption comes from oil. We would have to almost double our production from (Nuclear, Hydro, and Renewables). The distribution  would also nearly have to be double and that could include your own electrical panel in many cases.  
These ignore the problem of the outrageous cost of the batteries, short range. A big issue is carrying around  half of tonne of battery all the time. With gasoline  you are carrying around less than 60 kg on average vs 600kg with electric.  If you were to make a pickup capable of travelling 600km on a single charge most of the capacity would be lost due to the weight of the battery.

Comment: "The false connection between pipelines and climate change" is the only thing that has allowed financial resources and protesters to find common ground.  

Protesters want to keep oil sands crude in the ground, and they are being funded by U.S. mid-western refiners who want to keep oil sands crude landlocked, to suppress the market price of their feedstock, and maintain super-fat refining margins.  The false connection is the ruse that binds these unlikely partners on the same side of the issue.

The protesters are an unlikely group to catch on to how they are being used as pawns, but the refiners are going to recognize that the rising cost of opposing what is now a cabinet approved project will take an ever larger slice of their bloated refining margins.  The Canadian government can break the false connection by letting the refiners know that lawyers will be bleeding them dry if they persist in their duplicitous shenanigans.

Comment: "the dream of a nationally unified canada"

Because an older pipeline doesn't get repurposed, national unity is at risk?

The unifying aspect (had the pipeline proceeded) would have been the environmental risks shared by the four provinces crossed by the existing thin-walled pipe. 

By the way, I support the goal of self-sufficiency in oil supply and I'm not anti-pipeline. But EE was never the solution. Since the revival of Line 9 (which is even more thin-walled) much of eastern Canada's dependence on foreign oil has been reduced considerably. Consequently, most of EE's oil was destined for export, not domestic needs.

Comment: I drove to Anchorage and back today and did notice the de-icing system had sprayed on the South bound side, but not on the north bound side. Both were well sanded by the time I came back. The contractor had to come back and redo the calibrations on the system. The cost of the fluid is quite high, if I remember right. Working or not, one needs to approach those bridges on the defensive. Slow down before you go on, and be easy on the throttle and the brakes until you are well past the bridge. That is common sense, as bridges do ice up easily.

CRS 18-6-401. Child abuse
(1) (a) A person commits child abuse if such person causes an injury to a child's life or health, or permits a child to be unreasonably placed in a situation that poses a threat of injury to the child's life or health,...
...
(7) (a) Where death or injury results, the following shall apply:
(I) When a person acts knowingly or recklessly and the child abuse results in death to the child, it is a class 2 felony except as provided in paragraph (c) of this subsection (7).
(II) When a person acts with criminal negligence and the child abuse results in death to the child, it is a class 3 felony.
(III) When a person acts knowingly or recklessly and the child abuse results in serious bodily injury to the child, it is a class 3 felony.
(IV) When a person acts with criminal negligence and the child abuse results in serious bodily injury to the child, it is a class 4 felony.

Comment: "One should always have the understanding that when they run for public office their lives will change ... and if there are young families involved then at the very least the proper support systems are in place. "
.
What a facile comment.
.
You clearly have no idea of what is involved.
.
There is no such thing as a "proper support system".  In public office, the thing you no longer have is time:  your life belongs to the public to an extent that is hard to imagine.  You are expected to attend public events, and to make yourself available to the public almost every day, from first thing in the morning often until late at night.  Your family gets pushed to the margin.  You no longer have any privacy, and your family members run the risk of losing their privacy and being exposed to ridicule on a daily basis.
.
There is no "proper support system" that will ever change that truth.
.
Lots of talented people don't need that kind of life.
But without talented people, we get bad government.

Comment: I think that the idea of cultural appropriation CAN be an issue in criticism. It can generate some insights, such as those the author expressed in his example of the various types of forest gods in literature, poetry, art, etc. However, what could be a valid CRITICISM of a work of art isn't really what's being encouraged: what's being encouraged is a blacklisting of various works and their creators when they are deemed to have committed cultural appropriation. In other words, they are not saying "I see an appropriation of an idea that can only be expressed by people with such-and-such an experience/background/etc." They are saying "I see an appropriation of an idea that can only be expressed by people with such-and-such an experience/background/etc. Therefore, No One should be allowed to see/read/hear it." That's what should be debated here: not the criticism (people are free to criticize all they want) but the application of it through censorship.

Comment: Not really figures, but I'll accept the prohibition of any but local, Native hunters as more-or-less substantiating in lieu of other information.  However non-Native fishermen have taken their toll on beluga as well, which they regarded as competitors for salmon.  It's also simply not realistic to expect folks to accept avoidable injury and death in the name of "culture."  And if the AK F&W and US F&W service haven't attempted to negotiate with the Native nations to establish sustainable exploitation of the resource, they're not doing the job for which they're being paid.

The allocations for commercial marine species such as halibut, salmon, geoducks and even sea cucumbers for Native use and exploitation are legally established and defined in detail.  If this isn't the case with beluga, it's tempting to conclude it's not been given priority because there's no money for white commercial interests in similarly entering into a "partnership" with the Native folks to manage the species.

Comment: Why not send the special session to the area between (and including) Cantwell, Denali, McKinley Village, and Healy?  There are a lot of hotels opening up now in the area, and they won't have that much heavy traffic (their heavy time is June through July), and they should have a number of larger spaces that could hold the legislature.  As a bonus this area is halfway between the two largest cities, near the center of the state, and accessible by rail, road, and air (even smaller jets).  The state might get a great deal on rates just for the fact of them showing up would draw attention to the area for tourism purposes.  Kinda a win-win all around.

Note: I do not have any financial interests in the area.  In the early 2000's I drove a delivery route through the area (between ANC and FAI) dropping off at many of the hotels, lodges, and stores there.  I always thought all the hotels and lodges closed all winter was a waste of a resource.  To me it would be good for special sessions.

Comment: I'm not sure what you mean by the NPV being a red herring.  If both a Constitutional Amendment and the NPV have as the same outcome that every person's vote in this country would be equal to every other person's vote, where is the hocus pocus. There are no fractions, only people.  You either believe in the concept of people being equal under the law or you don't.  States are land masses.  Once you start to equate them with people you go down a very dark road.  People don't root for their candidate to win their state, they root for their candidate to win the presidency.  The only reason to oppose the NPV is if you prefer to have the balance of power maintained in your favor at all costs, even the lose of democracy.  I don't.

Comment: Excuse me, but most parents already pay taxes to support the DOE.  They have already paid plenty to the schools.  It's what schools--and some teachers--do with those resources that are often the problem.  There are needs, and there are wish lists.  There are must-have supplies and wouldn't-it-be-nice-supplies.  There are ways to recycle and wisely use items, and there are ways to waste items.  Another example is textbook purchasing.  In my experience, some teachers/departments took care of their textbooks, required students to protect them with paper covers, kept an inventory, and held students accountable for lost or damaged-beyond-repair books.  Others took little care of the $50 per copy books because, when they were lost, textbooks were considered a necessity and one could always get money to replace them or even buy brand new sets.  As for supplies, buying in bulk for a department or grade level from Fisher Hawaii or other suppliers does not create a HIDOE bureaucracy.

Comment: While fed and some state tax incentives for both have existed for more than 40 years in the US, I think it may be too late for these alone to do much good in anything other than a continued growth/full employment scenario. In any other scenario, e.g. jobless growth and/or mostly low-wage job growth, 

not to mention various types of stagnation, decline, and collapse scenarios, profit sharing and employee stock ownership could not only be useless, but could also result in employees losing income (especially in the case of stock ownership).

However, had either become the norm, rather than the exception, in corporate American at least 30+ years ago, they may have reduced the increase in income inequality resulting from the combo of automation and outsourcing (job exportation to cheaper labor markets) over the same time period. 

Such incentives MIGHT still be useful before automation runs its potential full course, but probably less so for the growing number of gig economy workers

Comment: I understand those concerns. The problem with cutting retirements and benefits and not keeping pace with inflation for wages however is it is getting harder and harder to hire people and even harder to retain the ones we have. Especially in the lower paying towns. If you are having to hire cops to replace the ones that leave every 2 years you are paying 36% more per cop because it takes up to 8 months to train the officers and get them on their own. That 8 months is the combined total of the academy and Field training.  It is actually cheaper to pay people a bit more to retain them or offer better benefits than it is to treat them like they are disposable. As for inflation I have been doing this for 17 years. I entered my wages into an inflation calculator and 17 years later I am only making $3 an hour more in real money from when I started. Health care costs have gone through the roof in the same time.

Comment: This is what happens to workers who are loyal to big corporate companies when there is no union representation to ensure their promised benefits are kept.  In the above article what seems to have happened over the past 65 years upper management and shareholders became increasingly more involved with their own profit taking and forgot about what made the retail market so big in the first place. The personal relationship between the front line salespersons and the repeat customer is what really makes retail shopping profitable. Comment: Well, actually, Harper was elected on roughly 23% of the vote, and Trudeau got a majority on 27% of the vote.  The big problem is turnout:  When Harper got his majority, turnout was only 52% of eligible voters.  For Justin Trudeau it was 61% of eligible voters.

By contrast, from 1921 to 1993 it was typically 68% to 74% of eligible votes.

When we got rid of door-to-door enumeration, turnout crashed.

When the Conservatives brought in voter ID, it took another drop down.

Now, since voter ID, roughly 22% fewer votes are cast in federal and provincial elections than previously, relative to the total potential voting-age population.

Lack of turnout has a huge effect on the legitimacy of the outcome of elections.

Other than abolishing FPTP, the most important thing we can do to rebuild the legitimacy of our elections is to bring back door-to-door household enumeration.

Comment: Of course. I too spent weekends at the pick-and-pull scavenging parts for my bimmer. Imagine what an ordinary person without the tools or skills would have paid for the same repairs. Then subtract the costs related to those engine, transmission, coolant, emissions controls and exhaust systems that an EV doesn't have. Is the number bigger or smaller? 

So what can go wrong? Pads & disks last much longer because of regenerative braking. The battery pack will lose very little capacity over 25 years. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gb_i4ihsJ1w) Time, rather than usage, seems to be the more significant factor. Electric motors are sealed units, are a proven technology in much harsher applications and extremely durable. The reduction gearbox is a sealed unit and much simpler than any automatic, CVT or manual transmission. I expect that the charger/inverter electronics are as durable as the ECU/EMU. Especially since they are not subject to the extreme heat and vibration of the IC engine.

Comment: A small business might be able to refuse a sale, depending on the reason, but after the sale has been made, the small business that refuses to be paid in U.S. dollars is the small business that doesn't get paid. There is a reason why U.S. currency states on its face "This note is legal tender for all debts public and private." It means that if you are offered U.S. currency/coins in lieu of a debt, you have no right to refuse it in settlement of the debt. If you do so, you refuse to be paid. Now, a business can refuse cash and only accept a check or an electronic payment, but the value will always be designated in U.S. dollars.

Comment: Billy you are making way too many assumptions based on practices from maybe one or two agencies. We have to work 25 years now to get full retirement (medical and 57.5% of our high 3 years). As for overtime I agree that the system has been gamed. The problem being that private companies like the sullivan areana have been allowed to pay for police overtime gigs but they don't pay for the retirement implications. However that is one agency in the state. My retirement when I hit 25 will not be enough to live on in Alaska and I will have to move or get another job.  Also its true if you eliminate the medical costs which has been done in Tier 4 the costs is the same if you had a 401K plan or a defined benefit plan.  Its actually costing the state more to screw workers over as less and less people are paying into the old plan causing deficits.

Comment: I vaguely remember when hardly anyone but the very rich had health insurance.  Generally, the medical profession charged no more than what the patients could actually pay.  In many places, setting a broken leg was "3 chickens and 2 dozen eggs".  Removing an infected appendix was "a hind-quarter, some back-strap, and a bushel of corn".  Then the insurance companies got big enough to spread the risk over a wider base ... which encouraged the medical profession to gradually increase their rates, because the insurance companies had deeper pockets ... to which the insurance companies responded by increasing their rates ... to eventually lead to the ACA.  Now we are much healthier, because we simply can't afford to get sick or injured.  We are no longer patients.  We have become a commodity.  We are "content" for the insurance/health video game!

Comment: We don't know for sure if large marine protected areas are going to save our oceans, and I don't think anyone is claiming this, especially given global warming. What some of us are saying is that the scientists recommend protecting large areas to help mitigate the inevitable impacts of warming, over-fishing, etc. The scientists also say that such areas are most effective if they are large, remote, protected for a long time, and enforced. So we'll see. No one knows for sure what will happen, but inaction is not an alternative for many of us.

Furthermore, many of us support fishing and never said fishing was evil (although some people think it is). We support the day-boat fishers and fought to exclude the areas near Nihoa and Necker from the monument. In addition, recreation, subsistence, and sustenance fishing will probably be allowed.  It's the industrial-scale commercial fishing that concerns us.

Last, many of us are addressing other ocean-related issues as well. Join our efforts!

Comment: I will disagree. 


And I don't agree that talking in generalities does not mean that what is being said is not--or should not--be taken personally. Making things personal is how we figure out what we may need to self-reflect on or whether it is a fair comment that needs to be considered--intellectually, emotionally, etc. There is no conversation that does not begin with the personal and work from that perspective. And there is no objective comment--we only try to come close to something more generalizable, "objective", universal, etc. 


You and I may just have, at the beginning, a philosophical difference on what is knowledge and experience. That's okay; we're just likely to meet up at the place we are at again. I do not consider this your defect or mine, but it may be the difference. And, our history here shows that sometimes we agree and sometimes we don't. This time we don't. 


Have a good move-on. Peace.

Comment: @rhockin: the real estate market has been rife with regulation/interference/special tax treatment all along, whether it's taxpayer-guaranteed mortgages(now pushing $1 trillion-with-a-"T") or criminally-low-penalty property tax deferral programs or the existence of any capital gains exemptions or "homeowner grants", etc. The point with pretty much all those measures is that they've all served to drive prices UP. When you add into the mix our ridiculously low rate environment, our choice to facilitate citizenship of convenience, and our tanking dollar relative to the USD or RMB, the affordability nightmare we now have has occurred.

I guess what I'm saying is: it's less about "more" vs. "less" regulation than it is about acknowledging 1) how unbalanced regulation has been and 2) that the only effective solution is for prices to fall (because I don't see everyone's wages suddenly tripling). Falling prices are the solution, whether they come from new policies or removing existing ones.

Comment: Sorry, but while you may think a renewal at the same institution is very different from a "refinancing" elsewhere, legally, not so much.  Your original lender is under NO obligation to "renew" you, despite what people believe.  When your term ends, you need somebody, somewhere to lend you the amount owing at that time, and if you don't like the conditions and rates offered, tough...   It is true that the measure, as now written, creates a significant bias to remaining with the original lender - but why should that only benefit the banks? It also means the credit unions, and any other lending firm, have an advantage in retaining their own loans.  The rules should just apply all over, period, but the government is dancing around trying to cool things without an outright crash.  But a crash is the only way to fix the market, and get back to prices at 3-4, or at most 5 times income.

Comment: Most of the comments here seem to be written by either supporters or haters of China. There seem to be two distinct opinions. 
PLease allow me to provide some perspective as somebody who has through his employment (recently retired) with one of Canada's largest retailers - three months each year travelling all over that country for more than 30 years. 
It is undeniable that China has improved - When I first went there the infrastructure was almost non existent, the poverty was heartbreaking, the pollution was simply incredible and there was virtually no social freedom. Over the 30 plus years there has been a giant improvement which is unequalled in any other country. However, there is still a great deal of work to be done. 
The haters still believe that it is still as it was 30 years ago and the supporters think that they have reached a pinnacle.
The truth is somewhere in between and I hope that Mr. Xi can continue to improve the lives of the Chinese people who deserve a better life.

Comment: Here is the counter argument.  You can invest the 1.5 million and earn 4-5% with no loss in capital, so that's $60,000 per year.  Since $60,000 per year is higher than the median annual income, most people will not be able to obtain a tax deferral benefit if RRSP limits are increased, or if other tax deferral strategies are allowed.  Above those limits, you pay the tax.  But you can hold money in your corporation; you'll only pay tax on the proceeds of the investment.   If you're holding a large amount of money in a corporation for a very long time, you could well take a 30% haircut on the money.  But you would have to pay more if you defer the withdrawal for too long, than if you had taken out the money as you went along and paid the tax.  The solution isn't to leave the money in and pay the 30%.   Take the money out, and pay the tax as you go along.  If the money is genuinely needed for dry periods, the investment proceeds and resulting tax aren't going to be anywhere near 30%.

Comment: sterling is not so sterling in his arguments.  first, funding rail using bonds will only drive up the cost of rail.  and as more bond funding is used by the city, the city's bond rating goes down and rates go up.  in the end the bonds will have to be paid back, this will place the burden on future generation.

his argument about sunk costs are circular.  completing rail in light of increasing costs is not throwing good money after bad.  rail is a vital component of Oahu's future, providing mass transit, affordable housing, quality of life for residents, etc .  most long term projects have cost overruns, but the trick is to deal with them the most efficient way.  the notion that cost overruns are inevitable so we should not attempt to build things is ridiculous.  

third, that only people that benefit from rail should pay for it - this is misguided.  there have been many projects, nationally and locally, that are funded by funds provided by people other that do not have direct benefit.

Comment: The level of scrutiny you advocate should be required of all real estate purchasers. They should have to prove that Canadian income taxes (or taxes in kind, in a country with a tax agreement with Canada) have been paid on all the money that is being brought to the purchase. This includes "gifts" from family members or other "supporters."  If such evidence isn't produced, levy an annual property tax rate equal to one-third the value of the purchase. In other words, a rate that seriously discourages dumping of untaxed wealth. Purchasers who can prove that they have paid their fair share of taxes on their wealth receive a "normal" property tax rate. Everyone knows that foreign capital is wrecking housing and land affordability, and, as the article confirms, this money can continue to find ways into the market by proxy through "non-foreign" buyers. The solution is to link real estate purchases to income tax. Demand that fed., prov. and municipal gov. cooperate to make it happen.

Comment: I agree 100%. Road tolls are inefficient. Furthermore, I'm not sure why road toll enthusiasts seem to think that they are the absolute only way of raising money for transit.

Let's face it, Tory doesn't want to be associated with raising taxes. Tolls are a way of avoiding that label, while simultaneously having the costs of the tolls borne in part by non-Toronto voters. It's win-win for him: he gets to say he didn't raise taxes and many of the people impacted by his decision can't vote for him anyway. Plus, he gets to foster the juvenile us-vs-them mentality regarding the 905.

There are a myriad of other ways to raise funds: raise property taxes, land transfer fees (plus, this may put a small damper on out-of-proportion real estate price escalations), parking, hotels, etc. Even if they wanted to float a special Toronto sales tax to the province it would only require the same approval that tolls would. And I'm sure the province would be happy to approve.

And I say this as a 416er.

Comment: "You do know that he was a decorated member of the colonial army before becoming a turncoat, right?" Um, yes.

The analogy ends there. The US government made a conscious decision to give amnesty & pardon those who fought for the south. Lee effectively ended the war by surrendering and kept it from restarting 2 years later by talking down those southerners who wanted to. He supported Johnson's plan for Reconstruction & became a symbol that aided its success. He was a productive, loyal member of American society the rest of his life.  He was neither pro-secession nor vehemently pro-slavery. He was a complex man (supported black education but not the right to vote); a product of his time. 

Where Arnold was ticked off at America & out for revenge, Lee fought the Union out of loyalty to his state, which democratically voted to secede. When he had the chance to bring the war to a close, he took it. Yes, he fought against his former country. But simplistic analysis of this man is impossible.

Comment: As a long proponent of the gas to liquids technology, a GTL plant on the North Slope can do several important things for Alaska.  A portion, up to 50% of the output of a GTL plant can be what is commonly referred to as a diluent.  In other parts of the world a diluent is used to extract heavy oil and in several parts of the Canadian tar sands programs a diluent is used to blend with their heavy crude to transport the heavy oil in pipelines.  We can do the same thing on the North Slope with a diluent to help extract this heavy oil and assist in the transport down TAPS to Valdez.  The diluent is recovered at the refinery and turned into valuable products.  Diluent will have a higher value than the heavy crude oil.  So the natural gas already on the North Slope can be turned into valuable liquids which can be shipped down TAPS to market and it can also be used to create a diluent to help extract and transport this heavy oil.  GTL's weren't available 20 years ago they are today.

Comment: All the comments were very good. 

I think the one troubling issue in the article was sovereignty. Given what has happened with Trump, and Europe, in recent months - that is huge. 

If the advocates are saying that Trade is for the people and not the corporations, they need to reduce the impact on national autonomy. 

A respected and highly credentialed columnist sounded the warning on a health policy threat that was most alarming: https://www.thestar.com/opinion/commentary/2016/12/12/donald-trumps-nafta-gambit-could-take-aim-at-medicare-walkom.html

You may not agree with his assessment of the risks. But if he is right about the principle, the threat to national autonomy is considerable. The potential backlash of voters, and rise of populists should be avoided.

More sovereignty friendly provisions should be welcomed on all sides to make citizens feel more secure, respected and that trade is a fair process. Otherwise reversing free trade is a real threat.

Comment: continue: 
SpaceX. 
LA Times made numerous accusations of SX depending on gov contracts. Fact is, that SX has the least number of gov contracts of ANY ROCKET LAUNCHER. They are less than 25% gov contracts. Most of theirs are private. 
But, note that SX has gotten subsidies of 300 M for COTS (cargo support for ISS) and somewhere between 1-2 Billion for CCdev (human space flight; starts in less than 1 year). 
Note that in return, SX is not only the cheapest launch system, but has forced others such as ULA to come way down. Where launches used to costs 200-500M for 11 tonnes to 28 tonnes respectively, SpaceX has pulled the price down to 60M (22 tonnes) and 90 M (64 tonnes ). In addition, within 2 years, launches will be 1/3 of these prices.
Add to that their new internet constellation that starts in 2019, and the ability to build satellites for a fraction of what any builder can today, we see that SX has changed our industry. 
We will go to the moon/mars SOLELY because of Musk and SpaceX.

Comment: That war should have never been fought. The South had a perfect right to leave peacefully. You probably don't know but there was a Confederate Peace Delegation in Washington before Ft. Sumter. They were to discuss the purchase by the South of federal property ( Including Sumter) located in the South, the payment by the Southern States of their portion of the federal debt and the setting up of diplomatic relation between the USA and CSA.
 Lincoln refused to meet with them. So did the Sec of State.  
Instead he sent two war ships and a  transport with 500 soldiers toward Charleston. 
Gen Beauregard didn't think he could defend the city against both the fort and warships and that the best course of action was to take the fort before the ships entered the harbour. 
 The ships never attempted to enter the harbour. Maj Anderson surrendered the fort and he and his men were transported under white flag to the Union fleet which returned to New York. No one was killed or even badly injured.

Comment: This really isn't a "neoliberal" policy in any normal sense of the word.

Neoliberalism is a modern take on "classical liberalism", the likes of John Locke and Adam Smith.  Modern neoliberalism is mostly based around economic prinicples from people like Fredreich Hayek, Ludwig von Mises and Milton Freidman who would certainly not be likely to argue in favour of such a 'bank'.

The proposed Infrastructure Bank, by contrast, is some sort of bastardization of Keynesian economics.  The justification for the spending is for government to boost economic activity (which would be Keynesian in nature except for the timing: we are near the peak of an economic cycle, not the trough).  The actual structure though seems to be based entirely around reducing transparency.

I think the best terms to describe this 'bank' would be "cronyism" and "corruption".  Such terms know no political boundaries.

Comment: Much as I dislike the LPC, I have to say that this scenario is acted out by all Parties in some degree.  As far as a Party riding candidate representing the riding electorate is concerned - wrong.  Party candidates represent the Party and will act in Parliament according to Party dictat.  The only riding candidate who is even remotely responsible to the riding is the Independent and even then, personal philosophy over-rides how the riding may feel on a particular issue.  No external force may subvert the Will of Parliament.

What the riding electorate does when voting is to choose the candidate who most closely expresses the electorate sentiment but an MP has NO legal obligation to the riding in Parliament.  Like it or not, that's how the Westminster system works.  The best the electors can hope for is that the elected MP actually does behave as they believed during the election campaign and at the risk of ejection from caucus, but that's as far as it goes.  Until the next election.

Comment: Essentially I agree, and that the party is headed for rump status if it stays the same, or fragmentation if a new leader tries to make changes unpalatable to the base too quickly. 

However, in Canadian politics a party only needs to be a plausible alternative to a government that has fallen into disfavour. If the Liberals blow it, a less extreme-sounding CPC with a credible leader would be in the running. In that case, it wouldn't take a great shift in policies to attract enough traditional conservative voters.

Unfortunately for the CPC, that strong potential leader with a salable vision doesn't seem to be in the running. I doubt the party will collapse the tent altogether by electing Kellie Leitch or Kevin O'Leary (although you never know...). Their best bet would be a safe, moderate candidate who can buy them time to revamp their platform and image.

Comment: While this sounds like a great idea, I think it would be better for the State of Alaska to re-institute the old school tax program . That way, anyone and everyone who earns over $100.00 while working in the state pays the tax once.
Forty years plus ago, the old school tax was  $10.00. But, with inflation increasing it to $100.00 makes more sense. 
Back in the days of the pipeline, there were many non-resident workers who came up here and spent their money South.  
The school tax was collected only once a year. It was deducted by employers from the first paycheck of every employee and sent to the state monthly. Employees kept that pay slip to show new employers, if employee changed jobs, that it was already paid.
In the event, for some reason the employee paid it more then once they could apply to have it returned by the state.
All the seasonal workers in the tourism business, fishing and processing, will be contributing along with any out of state residents who come up here to work.

Comment: Skeptical1 - with a $25 million deficit facing my new administration, large scale hiring was not possible. However, given the importance of public safety, we engaged the Police Executive Research Forum (PERF) to review our police department and make recommendations on how to be a more effective organization.  We followed those recommendations, including putting patrol officers on regular beats, reassigning officers from areas that they felt were over staffed, and adding officers once the fiscal health of the city was restored.  The results - crime was down every year and in my last two years, we held four police academies and those graduates are among the new officers on the street today.  Keep in mind, it's not only about the number of officers, but how they are deployed.

Comment: Its too bad. I am against changing the name from McKinley to Denali. Just to be honest in my opinion here. Mount McKinley isn't just an Alaskan mountain, but the highest mountain in the United States, and in North America. It doesn't just belong to Alaska but to the whole. Denali from all I read, is nothing but a bastardized colonial name by English speaking folks who can't pronounce the real native name. Isn't the real name " Dghelay Ka'a" or something close to that. And it doesn't represent all native people, just the people of the immediate area. There are other names for Mount McKinley of course. Naming a place for someone who never been there isn't anything new. Just look at Washington State, named after George Washington for example. Comment: How do business taxes work in terms of realizing gains?  If they are realized only on disposal like personal investments, this will create all different sorts of perverse incentives, because if a business has a buy and hold strategy for passive investments it could easily hit the 50k figure if it decides to reallocate its savings.  

As a result, this could both force lock-in to allow for longer compounding and in the hopes of these tax changes being fixed by a future government (which is frankly what has accelerated private corporation formatting in the first place given 53% marginal tax rates and the hope that at some point governments in Ontario and Ottawa will fix this), and also trigger unnecessary disposals to ensure that yearly gains get close to but do not exceed the 50k penalty threshold.

Both of those things are bad economics and bad business.  And all of this is to allow the government to get its hands on money faster than it would if it just waited.

He offered that he felt he was inadequately trained and didn't know where to turn to become competent. I really felt bad for him. And here he was working in a facility where there really isn't much in the way of competent staff.

Comment: It's obvious that Dana Milbank does not understand at least one thing about firearms: Specifically what constitutes an armor piercing bullet in regard to bullet proof vests.
Bullet proof vests are just that for nearly all handgun fired bullets. These bullets are propelled with gun powder charges that are smaller than those typically used in rifles (except the .22 caliber, rim fired), and the bullet noses are rounded rather than pointed as are most bullets used for hunting.
Center fired rifles, those where the primer is centered in the end of the casing, generally use larger casings allowing greater powder charges that propel a pointed bullet at velocities significantly greater than bullets fired from handguns. The pointed bullets and the greater velocities enable a typical hunting bullet to pierce bullet proof vests. Gun control advocates use this fact in an attempt to label typical hunting cartridges as "armor piercing". It's a prime example of cherry picking information.

Comment: Our adversarial system of justice requires that attorneys defend their client or prosecute the accused vigorously and legally, regardless of their personal beliefs. When Attorneys General choose to ignore the laws that exist rather than defending them vigorously, they appoint themselves as the judge, undermining the rule of law and the constitutional separation of powers. Such Attorneys General cannot be trusted by anyone and should resign or be fired immediately.

Comment: There needs to be some clarity about terminology here.  Non-human animals do not have rights recognized under any legal system I am familiar with.  This is because they are not recognized to have standing.  Only humans have justiciable rights.  Bambi, even through a human lawyer (and no lawyer-client relationship would be recognized there), cannot bring a wrongful death action against the hunter who shot his mother.

There are, to be sure, many statutes and regulations intended to protect non-human animals from, e.g., cruelty.  But those laws ultimately protect human interests.  Cruelty to animals is offensive to most people; protecting those sensibilities is one purpose of such laws. And you can argue that a human willing to inflict cruelty on animals may be more likely to injure his fellow men.  Litigation has been brought to effectuate such laws, but it must be brought by a human and must assert the human importance of seeing the statute enforced.

Comment: Some thoughts:
- Russia's nuclear success was based on espionage - Klaus Fuchs (German, then UK, then at Los Alamos) basically handed the USSR a complete bomb design document package.
- Bomb design as such - any nuclear physisicist could build a weapon, maybe not the most efficient but quite nasty anyway.

Comment: Most vessels that currently load in Vancouver go to refineries in Washington State,California or Hawaii, according to Thomson Reuters Eikon shipping data.
The Port of Vancouver, which houses Kinder Morgan's marine oil terminal, said it expects nearly 400 crude and chemical tankers a year under the expansion from 100.
The largest-sized oil tanker that can dock in Vancouver is an Aframax, which can carry 500,000 to 700,000 barrels. Vessels at the port can only be loaded up to 80% capacity due to depth and other restrictions, meaning a vessel can only be filled to around 550,000 barrels. 
As long as the port can only take Aframax, it will remain largely "uneconomical" for exports to head to Asia. Traders said the price of Canadian crude shipped to Asia needs to be low enough to offset the cost of shipping across the Pacific on smaller vessels.
Crude oil exports to countries other than the U.S. represents only 0.8% of Canada's total crude oil production, around 25,000 b/d on average.

Comment: Dante, I'm not sure what point you're trying to make other than "I don't like companies being successful".

In a competitive environment people are free to select whatever provider they like for goods and services.  If they are willing to pay more for better service they can do so.

As for the 407, I've used it and it is hugely convenient for certain trips.  I know many people find it to be well worth the cost.  Others might not find the cost worthwhile and they are in no way obligated to use the 407.  Everywhere the 407 goes there is another highway near by that goes to roughly the same place.

Also, keep in mind that we didn't have to pay a dime to nearly double the length of the 407 after it was leased, we haven't had to pay for any of the upgrades or maintenance and we don't even have to pay for policing the highway (or, more accurately, the 407ETR pays the OPP to cover the full cost of policing the highway).

All this would otherwise be paid using higher taxes.

Comment: Years ago my wife and I got swept down a very fast moving glacier fed creek. We fell, had water flowing over our heads and were bounced along the bottom on the cobbles. Fortunately she was able to grab a branch and pulled us out of the main flow to the side where the water was slower. We were only in the water for maybe a minute but were freezing cold and our feet were numb. She actually started turning blue. The bad thing is we ended up on the same side we started from and still had to cross it again. I gained a lot of respect for swift, cold water that day and have no desire to repeat the experience. 

Later I spoke with a swift water rescue volunteer who said there is a danger of a persons foot getting trapped under a large, shifted cobble and eventually succumbing to the cold and drowning. I'd never thought about that possibility before.

Comment: You boys can reflexively thumb down, but there is a wide body of research indicating data technology increases administrative costs. Perfectly logical, it requires input, cleaning and analysis. Justifying such a investment is then contingent on how such data is used - what is the return?

In health care, data has for decades been the panacea or silver bullet for rising costs. But lots of research indicating problems with such lofty expectations. Some examples:

Savings Utility or Extra Cost: Way back in the 1970s, the Ontario government through what is known as HMRI introduced a new data system to capture information on patient care. Such data would be used to identify care improvement/cost savings. Studies indicated that while the data system imposed new administrative costs, the data itself was not really used to change medical practice and resource utilization. At best, it was used to negotiate funding with the Ministry of Health. At worst, it was collected because they had to.

Comment: Let us grant that it is possible for homosexual priests to think they are not homosexuals. It cannot be said more emphatically that this changes nothing. If someone eats nothing but vegetables and does not consider himself to be a vegetarian, this is surely an interesting psychological issue, but it does not change reality. Subjectively, the vegetarian may think of himself as carnivorous, but his behavior belies his self-perception. Homosexuals, like vegetarians, are defined by what they do, not by what they believe themselves to be.

The authors  of the John Jay Study gathered clinical data from treatment centers, places where troubled priests were assigned. What they found was that “three quarters of the priests whom we have data had sexual relations with an adult and/or minor after ordination.”

Given that the minors were mostly male, and beyond puberty, is this not clearly an issue of homosexuality?
