Comment: People who use cars for their primary transportation don't provide "goods to stores, emergency needs, communication, construction, etc." They actually obstruct those truckers, EMTs, and others who use the roadways out of necessity. How many times have you seen an ambulance honking while cars backed up at a traffic light clumsily attempt to get out of the way? As for tourism, almost every major urban destination in the world is notable for walkable streets, bike infrastructure, and public transportation. That's what boosts tourism. 

Studies on the ROI of investing in car vs. cycling infrastructure come down clearly on the side of cycling. Car use is incredibly expensive and heavily subsidized by taxes. Car infrastructure tends to make traffic worse (a phenomenon called induced demand), encourages "big box" developments that hurt local economies, and makes cities less safe and less healthy. Cycling does the opposite. 

And, as you point out, cyclists already share the costs of road.

Comment: The Scarborough RT is being dismantled because its capacity (4,000 pphpd, max. people/hour) is woefully inadequate — right now, 4,600 pphpd are cramming it at rush hour. And because it's orphaned technology which never caught on, for which we can't get replacement parts. It's even artificially slowed down to minimize breakdowns in its remaining years.

The LRT is standard technology successfully used around the world, supported by several vendors; the total opposite of the orphaned RT. And with a capacity of 15,000 pphpd, it would comfortably serve commuters for several generations. Plus, its low cost leaves billions available to build even more rapid transit across Scarborough — as of now, similar money would bring Scarborough either 1 stop (subway), or 24 stops (LRT) on two full lines.

Post opinions if you wish, but you will always be fact-checked.

Comment: Indeed administrators make obscene profits. Discovery Health makes a 40% profit on their scheme administration. That is way above what margins most companies make on the JSE. Discovery Medical scheme trustees are failing, in that they are not asking why they are overpaying to such an extent. Their previous KPMG report checked whether they get value for money, but apparently did not question whether they should be paying less, in fact. One can have a virtual pooling of risk in a Risk Equalisation Fund without physical pooling in one or two schemes.  All the positives of pooling, along with competition still happening to drive innovation. Restructuring options is another way to help

Comment: The conservatives on the Lane Board of Commissioners are the very ones to decry "the nanny state" wherein government makes decisions for citizens.  Ironically, they propose a new county statute giving them the power to veto an initiative proposal, bringing that "nanny" concept to a new level.  

The initiative process is a time-honored feature of Constitutional democracy.  It's the most powerful direct tool for citizens to promote new laws and, if they're favored by voters, have them adopted.  Efforts to place governmental controls, and a veto is the most draconian control possible, over the intitative process are inherently anti-democratic.

There will be initiatives, just as there will be recalls, with which you, I and the County Commissioners may agree or disagree.  We have every opportunity to support, or, should we choose, oppose them.  That's the process we call democracy.  The LCBC needs to reject this arrogant, patronizing proposal.  It's a terrible idea.        Gary Crum

Comment: I have donated gallons of blood to the Blood Bank.  The numbers of donations and the numbers of sold units don't add up to 1/6th of the supply.  If you look at the scheduled whole blood donations BBA's donor site for the next week in Anchorage Center, Dimond Mall, Fairbanks, and Wasilla, you get 115 donations scheduled next week.  Let's add 10 drop-in donors and 30 donations per day on the bus (M-Sat).  240 + 115 donotions = 355.  I'm not seeing 600 donations per week every week.  The article said BBA had 232 units in quarantine last week.  Question:  If we had a mass casualty event, plane crash, shooting, etc., and the 100 units just got shipped out that day, would there be enough blood locally to handle the demand?  How many people would die waiting for new blood to arrive from Outside?  What do hospitals expect from BBA in terms of emergency backup?  I don't mind if my blood is discarded -- if having it on the shelf means people who would have died live.  BBA -- we count on you.

Comment: Adam

You sound like you are grasping to defend your post. 

When we bought our home in the 1980s, we didn’t know where rates were going.  I can tell you it was a struggle to stay above water since just the interest on our mortgage was almost 25% of our net income. 

I will say that those same interest rates kept our expectations in check. 

The low interest rates of today allow people to borrow well beyond their actual needs. Unfortunately these same people don’t have anyone sit them down and show them the consequences of higher rates. We didn’t need that because higher rates were in our face. 

As it turns out, rates did not continue to rise and for us it worked out well. 

Someone who bought a reasonable home 8 years ago (not the MAX they could afford) and made a few extra payments would be in fine financial shape now. 

We have known for a while rates would rise, the writing was on the wall. Those that recently have gone all out in RE will have to live with that choice.

Comment: This is a very good site for such a development. It's next to the campus, not on the edge of the river and has access to other amenities for its residents. It's about time we started getting some double-digit floor buildings in this place.

I am a bit dismayed at the huge amount of parking that is planned. Good grief, they're going to be building an extra 20% just to store cars. What a 1950's approach; that's both wasteful and stupid, imo.

For those who question the need for more student housing, there is a positive knock-on effect to a glut of student housing for everyone who is not a landlord. If the students move out of housing in the general city, those units will be freed up and perhaps even become more affordable for other people in the community. Sure, we landlords and property owners can make more money by restricting supply, but that doesn't make Eugene a better place to live.

Comment: What I see is a lot of reductionism. Under the fire of modern morality, a complex piece of history is boiled down to a single issue.

Before the Civil War, Robert E. Lee was already an American hero for his service to the nation. It's known that he considered slavery an evil. He joined the losing side in the war, but was a brilliant commander. After the war he acted for reconciliation between the two sides, in an effort to reunite the country.

Just like human beings, history is complex, messy, even confused at times. Simplistically reducing it to good guys and bad guys is rarely beneficial.

Comment: BoC should have raised interest rates 5 years ago.  They are well below neutral and are even well below the FED rate, which historically is extremely uncommon.   I don't disagree that the BoC's windshield is hard to see through but I disagree with the premise that inflation is low.  Yes, CPI is low (but not inflation) but one needs to understand how it's calculated before saying that inflation is low.  A large part of CPI is home ownership  cost, which remains low due to low mortgage interest rates over the past 5 years.  Imagine what would happen to mortgage interest rates if the BoC rate rises?
When I look around at what I spend my money on everything is more expensive.  Food costs are rising faster than the S&P index.  Muni taxes for the last 5 years have averaged about 8% per year.  Fuel is more expensive.  Inflation is much higher than 1.3%.

Comment: So many people seem to function under the concept that the US government is supposed to be altruistic institution.  But the truth of the matter is the framers of the Constitution recognized that people are self-interested.  That special interests will always have influence, if not outright control, over government decisions.  Thus one of the reasons why power was separated into three branches _and_ why special interests are invited to play in politics.  To wit, to prevent power from concentrating in too few hands for too long.  Take a look at ethical regulations.  They are relatively new (and typically fledgling) creations in the federal government.

Comment: Veritatis Splendor is essentially Saint John Paul's redux of the Syllabii on Error by Blessed Pius IX and Saint Pius X.  It is a rear guard action in defense of the fantastic Natural Order and a doctrine of original sin that presupposes the reality of the Eden myth.  It is essentially anti-pastoral.  It would refreshing if Pope Francis preached a more realistic view of morality - one that existed in the lives of the people involved rather than one based on the old superstitions of doctrine past.  Sins happen to people, not to God or some natural order idealized by the Vatican.  Amoris Laetitia is an attempt to break us out of that cycle.  While many of us would welcome a repudiation of faith as superstition, many of the weak of faith, including the four ex-pastors, would not be able to handle it.  Faith is not loyalty to the Church, it is trust in God and His benevolence to people in pain.

Comment: Fish Forensic Science. So how do you identify what species another fish was praying on by looking at it's stomach contents? Lots of fish skeletons of different species are very similar in appearance and most of the soft tissues might be pretty much digested. Well every fish has a couple of bones that are thicker and tougher than most and remain in a fishes stomach longer too. These are the two otoliths, more commonly called ear bones, located on either side of the fishes head. Every fish has them and the every species has a different shape of otolith. They are usually only 2 or 3 millimeters wide in Alaska fish and they grow as the fish does and gets growth rings so they can be used to tell the fishes age. They can also tell us what humans were catching by locating them at archeological sites. I illustrated the guidebook... Believe it or not.

Comment: University of Michigan environmental scientist Rosina Bierbaum: “The U.S. is well behind other countries in having the cleanest and most sustainable environment.”

The U.S. emits more carbon dioxide than any other nation except China. In 2014, the U.S. spewed 237 times more carbon dioxide into the air than Sweden, according to figures by the U.S. Department of Energy’s Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

The U.S. is No. 2 in per person carbon dioxide pollution, behind Luxembourg, among 35 developed nations plus China, India and Brazil, Energy Department data show. That’s 19.1 tons (17.3 metric tons) of carbon dioxide per year for the average American, compared with 4.9 tons (4.5 metric tons) for the average Swede.

The U.S. ranks tenth highest in carbon pollution per gross domestic product according to the International Energy Agency. The U.S. spews almost five times more carbon dioxide per dollar in the economy than Sweden.

William K. Reilly, former EPA head, says Trump is "just wrong."

Comment: Of course, if the entire human race sits on its hands and does nothing, the costs will be far, far higher for Canada and everyone else. This article is written to imply that the science of climate change in uncertain, but the only real uncertainly left is how quickly we are heading for disaster if we do nothing.

Without actually being able to see and review the report, of course, it is impossible to evaluate its assumptions. Energy retrofits to buildings often lead to net economic savings in the longer term, for example. The price of wind and solar power are rapidly falling and, in many places, it is already less expensive to generate power by those means than with coal or oil. Battery technolgies are improving rapidly and electric vehicles are far more efficient than internal combustion engines. So, does the report take all these factors into account, or is it simply a smokescreen (literally) for continuing business as usual for the fossil fuel industry?

Comment: I'm disappointed, Globe Editorial Board.  You express shock that politician who has arisen to the position of Prime Minister is "calculating", as though that's a bad thing -- in reality, it's a necessary prerequisite for anyone in a position of leadership!  And anyone subject to the intense scrutiny of such a position will be found to have unflattering qualities of some sort.  Justin Trudeau and Stephen Harper are human, and their effectiveness as leaders should be judged based on their policies.  Journalism increasingly is turning all coverage of politics into a personality contest, which is a disservice to all Canadians.  When you focus on these issues incessantly as you do, readers will view them as more important -- more important than actual issues they seek to address.  Please, Globe, leave the empty personality assassination to lesser publications, and focus your editorials on politician's actual records, not their perceived ones.

Comment: The problem is that the voucher systems that have been proposed would destroy public education, rather than build it up, and their benefits are grossly overstated.

Firstly, they're ethically and legally questionable in that some of them would go to religious schools, which would possibly violate prohibitions on government funded religion.
Secondly, vouchers do not increase access to higher quality education, do not save taxpayer money, do not improve low- to middle-income opportunities and do not ultimately improve academic performance.

They do however, draw funding away from public schools that are accessible to all students, and result in a general decline in the quality of public education. This becomes something of a self-fulfilling prophecy as it then motivates more parents to withdraw students, further decreasing school budgets, further lowering the educational quality.

Comment: I understand your situation, as I'm paying much more than you were. I'm sympathetic to the situation. But here's a couple of points; 1) Individual market insurance is age based, and gets much more expensive as you get older. It always has. If this law passes, that maximum age multiple goes from 3 times to 5 times a young person's premium. 2) The cost driver in Alaska under Obamacare (PPACA) has been allowing already sick people to buy insurance. That doesn't go away under the proposed American Health Care Act. 3) Going the asset protection route might very well be sensible from an individual's point of view, but it means that those that pay for insurance before they "need" it, like me, will be the ones that pay for the cost of your care, should you or your family end up with an expensive, serious, medical situation. In my opinion, the mandate combined with subsidies that limit the cost of insurance to some maximum percentage of income for ALL income levels is a reasonable compromise.

Comment: Mr. Cole offers solutions that have bankrupted our country: Take people's wealth and spend it. The PF was NOT created for this occasion; it was created to keep money out of the hands of politicians. Why? Because they squander it. Alaska is among the least taxed states because we're young. Cut HHS, tax subsidies and Education by $500m; restore the full dividend; change DOL laws so people benefit more from work than unemployment!

Comment: I looked at their analysis and cannot figure out how they arrived at that recommendation.

Sure its relative valuation is higher than its peer group, but look at the peer group - the only one that is doing as well in terms absolute performance is Capital Power Corp. In other words, comparing AQN to a bunch of underperforming dogs is going to make it appear relatively overvalued.

It's revenue and net income continues to grow, and will continue as earnings accrue from its acquisition of Empire. Future acquisition plans reflect strong growth potential.

Their debt is a bit high (but not out of line with the sector) and in the last Q it paid dividends that were 100% of EPS. For me, though, a company that does not take advantage of low interest rates and the ability to write off debt expenses is foolish. As well, the forecasted EPS is to continue growing.

All in all, this company has been well managed over the past few years, and appears to have a lot of potential ahead.

Comment: As in many institutions and individuals alike, TWU's belief is that sex is only permissible within the confines of marriage, and that marriage is only valid between one man and one woman. One can easily see how that belief isn't shared by non-heterosexuals. But let's say that TWU decided to stand by its belief, while removing the article in its covenant that forbids sex outside of a man-woman marriage. Would LGBTQ individuals then choose to attend the university? Given the dissonance between the two beliefs, one can safely assume not, even though LGBTQ students would no longer face a discriminatory rule.

The reality is that even were TWU to rescind its rule on sexual activity, it will not persuade LGBTQ students to seek a law degree there. So in refusing to accredit TWU's law school, the Law Society of Upper Canada can achieve no practical good. They're attempting to fight discrimination with further discrimination. That never works.

Comment: Last night after dusk I went out to my small orchard to look at stars.  Little brown bats, locally the most common species, fluttered around me scooping up flying insects invisible to my eyes.  However, I have seen only one big brown bat this year, and their usual daytime roost, a collapsing barn, has none in it for two years now.  Maybe white nose syndrome?  Here along the Siuslaw River we have bees and wasps of all kinds, and lots of spiders.  I think the populations of birds and insects vary year-to-year and by locale.  At least, I hope so.  Honey bees probably suffer from varroa mites and other parasites, and are susceptible to infection when hives are moved around the country and into contact with infected colonies.  My orchard is crowded with bug-eating birds.

Let's work to ban neonicotinoid insecticides, which are cumulative and long-lasting poisons; and let's limit herbicide spraying to protect aquatic  phytoplankton, the base of the food chain for all aquatic insect nymphs.

Comment: As an ethnic entity, Tibet and its people formerly relied on their remoteness to protect them from the outside world. The Tibetan people are being assimilated and their lands are being exploited. I have great empathy for the Tibetans and their way of life. Resistance has proven futile. Tibetans need a new strategy if they're to preserve their culture.

Comment: You're assuming that the amount of short wave radiation coming in is constant.  It isn't.  The Earth receives variable amounts of radiation coming in, not only from the sun, but from other stars.  And what we receive from the sun varies with sunspot activity, which has far more influence on climate change than the composition of greenhouse gases, documentable by historic correlations between temperature and sunspot activity that are far more direct and consistent than the correlation with CO2 concentration.  And that's a scientific fact.

Other important variables include our position relative to the sun in our ever-changing elliptical orbit and the ever-changing tilt of the Earth's axis, which might explain why it may be warmer now in the Northern hemispere where you gather most of the data, and cooler in the Southern hemisphere where you gather very little.  It doesn't serve the agenda to get an actual average global temperature, so you cheat.
(cont'd)

Comment: The problem with attempting to write a law that's sometimes viewed as unenforceable is that it might be that it's illegal to prohibit certain actions, so compromise has to be reached until new court cases can create new precedents.

Plus the first wave of distracted driving laws were written before smartphones made handheld Internet access ubiquitous, just as our first law was written in 2008.

A court case threw out the old outmoded law, hence the need for a new one.

True, Gara sponsored changes, but BIll Thomas was a co-sponsor too.

Neither of the two can be said to have been the only writers.

As to who 'wrote' the statute, there was the old law, plus amendments put forward and what resulted from the committee process just the same as other legislation does. 

 The final wording is seldom one person's doing.  

Through the dictates of the courts, the old law's content, the revision effort and the amendments, a bill became law.

Kind of why we have the kind of government we do.

Comment: While certainly the DB plan is less common today for those still working, a fair number of current retirees from the private sector have DB plans.

Further, despite the nostalgia around DB plans it is a myth that DC plans (and less formal savings plans) are inferior to DB plans.   Both have advantages and disadvantages and neither are bulletproof.  The major difference of course is that DC plans and savings plans require the employee to be more proactive and engaged in the process.  Which obviously a huge negative for those not inclined to manage their own finances.  But the huge positive is that the upside is not limited and you have greater flexibility in how you structure your finances.

I have never had a DB plan, and only had a formal DC plan for about 3 years (now part of a LIRA).  For the rest of the time I have either had a savings plan as an employee or built that into my hourly rates as a contractor.

I don't envy the DB pensioner one bit.

Comment: I'm a testing Coordinator at a public Middle School in the metro area and I'm going to tell you a secret. Students aren't tested heavily in Colorado.

The PARCC exams are state mandated for grades 3-10 and require three sixty minute sessions each. They are over a month long testing window. Most schools spread them over a week. The only other state mandated exam are for students designated as English Language Learners (They take an six part that takes about two hours total). Students in 11th grade also take the SAT. 

That means that most students are only in mandated testing six hours a YEAR. 

Any other acronym exam they take, STAR (for math) or SRI (for reading), are 15 minute, non-mandated, placement tests that help teachers drive instruction and aren't something kids can "opt-out" of just like a kid can't opt out of his US History midterm. 

But hey, the same people complaining about testing want high stakes accountability for kids... you can't have your cake and eat it too.

Comment: A rather crude mis-analogy. In that situation, a person who is drinking can take steps prior to becoming impaired so resolve the situation, i.e. they can take their keys and remove them from their person, or arrange another route home ahead of time. 

In the case of sexual assault, it takes two to tango. It is reasonable for the law to state that someone who is incapacitated from alcohol cannot give consent for sexual activity to another person, and that other person has the responsibility to obtain knowing consent. 

What happens if the other person cannot tell if the 'victim' is incapacitated? What happens if both parties are intoxicated? Good questions, requiring the application of judgment and context in the legal system. But it doesn't violate a general premise that those who are intoxicated are incapable of giving their consent to sexual activity with another and are victims, but nonetheless must be held responsible for driving while impaired.

Comment: A few basic facts:
Pesticides have been used extensively for over 80 years and there still has not been even one confirmed illness or death from consuming their residues on foods.
Pesticides are safety tested extensively for 7 years BEFORE they are approved for public use.
These tests are so extensive that it costs companies over $250 million dollars. If ANY of these thousands of safety tests are failed, the product is denied approval.
Virtually every product you store under your sink is more toxic than most pesticides.
i.e. bleach, paint, ammonia, oven cleaner, table salt, etc.
AND these pesticides are only applied at 8-32 fluid ounces PER ACRE.
When you use the same reasoning as a toxicologist, you discover the risk is very low.
For example: A pesticide which is less toxic than table salt at full concentration, is applied at 32 fluid ounces per acre......poses virtually no negative risk to people or the environment.

Comment: And then there is the hurdle of clearing the international bar on legalizing marijuana that is embedded in various UN drug conventions and treaties of which Canada is a signatory - the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, the 1971 Convention on Psychotropic Substances and the 1988 Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances.

And it is not as if Trudeau is unaware of the international problems, he just seems to ignore them.

“Canada is party to three international drug conventions,” reads a briefing note prepared for the prime minister after his election. “All three require the criminalization of possession and production of cannabis. As part of examining legalization of cannabis possession and production, Canada will need to explore how to inform the international community and will have to determine the steps needed to adjust its obligations under these conventions.”

Comment: They should be allowed to have a referendum to decide this question along with clear rules set.  The fact that the central government is forbidding it and declaring it illegal is a problem.   

But if the government is telling voters not to vote, and in some cases will surely prevent some from voting, then how legitimate will a yes vote be if only the yes side goes out to vote.   

If they don't get anywhere close to 50%+ of the total eligible voters to vote yes, I can't see how any nation will side with the Catalan government.
